thread.title: Australian shoppers among the most digitally influenced in the world: report
thread.title_full: Australian shoppers among the most digitally influenced in the world: report

author: Patrick Hatch
title: Australian shoppers among the most digitally influenced in the world: report
text:
Deloitte says shoppers who were influenced by social media platforms were 25 per cent more likely to make a purchase. Photo: Reuters
Australian shoppers are some of the most digitally influenced in the world, with a majority now going online to research the products they want to buy before visiting a store.
Sixty-five per cent of those interviewed research online before going shopping, 26 per cent do so during their shop, and 9 per cent do so afterwards, a new report by Deloitte says.
Shoppers told Deloitte that 40 per cent of visits to brick-and-mortar stores are digitally influenced, putting Australia third in the world behind the US and Canada (49 per cent and 41 per cent), but ahead of comparable nations like Germany (30 per cent) and the UK (27 per cent).
The report, Navigating the Digital Divide , shows 72 per cent shoppers arrive at a store already knowing what they want to buy after looking online, compared with 28 per cent who have been influenced by traditional advertising.
Advertisement "When it comes to validating their purchase, consumers trust neutral sources of information over retail advertisements," the report says.
"Reviews are their preferred method, with discussions with family and friends coming a close second."
The report shows 49 per cent of shoppers read reviews, 46 discuss what they want to buy with family and friends and 18 per cent talk to shop assistants.
The most common online activities during a shopping trip are comparing products (47 per cent), accessing product information (42 per cent) and checking product availability (33 per cent).
On average, 21 per cent of shoppers think they spend more money instore because of their digital activities, while that number jumps to 34 per cent for people in the 18 to 24 age bracket.
Social media has also emerged as a lucrative tool for retailers, with shoppers who were influenced by social platforms 25 per cent more likely to make a purchase because of it.
The power of different platforms is split along gender lines, with YouTube influencing 36 per cent of men, followed by Facebook (31 per cent), blogs (21 per cent), company-specific blogs (21 per cent) and then Twitter (17 per cent).
Women are most influenced by Facebook (36 per cent), YouTube (31 per cent), company-specific blogs (22 per cent), Pinterest (20 per cent) and Instagram (18 per cent).
Some categories appear more affected by the growing digital influence, with electronics being the most (53 per cent of shoppers), followed by baby and toddler accessories (48 per cent), automobile (47 per cent) and furniture (46 per cent).
Digital influence has multiplied four times over the past three years in the US and Australian could follow a similar pattern here, the report says.
